I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Water is central to human existence. It is also a key factor in reducing poverty, improving 
livelihoods, and promoting economic growth. Authority for managing the world's fresh water 
resources is  fragmented  among  the  world's  nations,  hundreds  of  thousands  of  local 
governments,  and  countless  nongovernment  and  private  organizations,  as  well  as  a  large 
number of international bodies. Management issues have been subjected to numerous studies 
and  debates,  particularly  the  world  water  forums  (WWFs)  organized  by  the  World  Water 
Council. 
 
2.  ADB participated in the last three WWFs held in the Netherlands (2000), Japan (2003), 
and Mexico (2006) and made significant contributions at the last two.1 At the third WWF in 
Japan, ADB announced several partnerships, including the Water for Asian Cities Program. At 
the fourth WWF in Mexico, ADB announced the Water Financing Program (WFP) 2006–2010.2 
The WFP will guide ADB in responding more effectively to the Asia and Pacific region’s critical 
water investment needs and double ADB’s investment in water operations for 2006–2010.3  
 
3.  At the fourth WWF, the Japan Water Forum (JWF) and five subregional coordinators 
(Korea Water Forum, Global Water Partnership [GWP] South East Asia, GWP South Asia, GWP 
Central Asia, and the Pacific Islands Applied Geoscience Commission) reported on the progress 
and formidable water-related challenges in the Asia and Pacific region and proposed that an 
Asia-Pacific Water Forum (APWF) be established.4 A ministerial declaration at the fourth WWF 
established the APWF as an independent, not-for-profit, non-partisan, and non-political network. 
The APWF was launched at ADB on 27 September 2006, during a WFP conference. JWF will 
serve as the secretariat. This proposed regional technical assistance (TA) will support ADB’s 
contribution to the APWF for two years (2007–2008). The TA design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1.5  Background information on the APWF is in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The Asia and Pacific region has done better than other parts of the developing world in 
improving access to and management of water. However, rapid population growth, urbanization, 
and the underperformance of existing water assets mean there is a large shortfall in meeting the 
region’s needs. In 2005, about 700 million people in the region were still without safe water 
supplies and some 2 billion had inadequate or no toilet facilities.

5.  Investments to provide people with safe drinking water and decent sanitation facilities, to 
allocate  and  preserve  water  resources,  and  to  manage  wastewater  properly  have  fallen 
seriously behind demands. The Asia Water Watch 2015 study, commissioned by ADB, World 
Health Organization (WHO), United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), and United 
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP), estimated that 
annual investments of at least $8 billion will be needed in the Asia and Pacific region over the 
next decade if countries are to meet Millennium Development Goal (MDG) targets for safe 
drinking water and sanitation.6   
 
6.  Significant investments are also needed in irrigation services, river basin management, 
flood management and mitigation, and wastewater management. Investments in water are 
crucial  to meet  the  broader  MDG  targets  of  reducing poverty,  hunger,  child and  maternal 
mortality and the incidence of major diseases, and to improve environmental sustainability. 
Clearly, this is a major challenge, and one that is complicated by a wide range of governance, 
institutional, social, environmental and political issues. There is also a need to drastically reduce 
the vulnerability of human populations to water-related disasters.7  
 
7.  In calling for the creation of the APWF, the region’s water ministers sought to establish 
an  effective  mechanism  to  encourage  more  collaborative  efforts  on  financing  water 
infrastructure and to accelerate the effective integration of water resource management into the 
socioeconomic development processes of the region. The ministerial meeting in March 2006 
also called upon the APWF to organize Asia-Pacific water summits (APWSs) once every 2 or 
3 years.  It was agreed that first summit would be held in Japan in 2007.8  
 
8.  Since 2001, as part of the activities supported by the Cooperation Fund for the Water 
Sector (CFWS),9 ADB has produced, among others, publications on water and poverty, the 
performance of utilities, comprehensive analyses of water sector reforms, and sector road maps 
for developing member countries (DMCs); papers on dams and water for all; a multimedia toolkit 
on sanitation; and model terms of reference on water supply and sanitation.10 In keeping with its 
reputation as an authoritative source of knowledge about the water sector in the region, ADB 
also  supports  its  DMCs  to  prepare  water  sector  reviews  and  sector  road  maps.  ADB’s 
knowledge products on the water sector are among the most downloaded documents from its 
website. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will promote sustainable water management policies and practices in the Asia 
and Pacific region by establishing a common platform for advancing strategies for solving water 
problems. The TA will also support major regional events, including the first APWS, which will 
bring together leaders of governments, the private sector, and civil society. It will showcase

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will deliver two outputs: (i) the Asian Water and Development Outlook (AWDO), 
and (ii) regional events, including the first APWS in Japan in 2007. 
 
11.  AWDO. Under the TA, ADB, in its capacity as the lead institution for boosting water 
financing and increasing public outreach, will commission a flagship report, the AWDO. The 
AWDO will draw on ADB's Asian Development Outlook, Asian Environmental Outlook, UNDP's 
Human Development Report, and publications by Transparency International, among others. 
The  AWDO  will  directly  target  senior  government  officials  involved  in  making  investment 
decisions (principally finance and planning ministers and their advisers). It will showcase good 
practices that have helped overcome challenges. It will include background analytical papers on 
issues affecting the priorities for the water sector and boosting water investments; an overview 
of the water sector in the region; and country profiles containing analysis and statistics on key 
water sector indicators.  
 
12.  In addition to showing progress in countries, the AWDO will introduce one or more new 
indicators  to  track  country  leadership  and  results  in  water  governance  that  will  affect 
investments, reforms, and capacity development. The AWDO will stimulate government leaders 
to champion a water agenda for their countries. It will articulate the overall directions for water 
activities that will be promoted by APWF in the coming years. The AWDO will be presented at 
the  first  APWS,  with  a  declaration  by  the  leaders  supporting  the  key  messages  and 
recommendations in the AWDO.11 The packaging of the document will take into account the 
time constraints of the target audience.   
 
13.  First APWS. The Government of Japan will host the first APWS in Beppu City, Oita 
Prefecture, with cabinet approval. APWF and a ministerial-level steering committee consisting of 
eminent persons from Japan and other countries in the region will be responsible for organizing 
the first APWS. The primary objective of the APWS is to create an opportunity for the political 
leaders of the region to commit to address the water issues that will affect achieving the MDGs.  
Each APWS will target heads of governments and ministers of finance and planning, as well as 
leaders from the private sector, local governments, civil society, and media in the region,12 with 
a view to moving water to the top of countries’ political agendas. 
 
14.  The first APWS will help leaders from the region, and partner organizations, to tap into 
new sources of finance and to develop innovative financial mechanisms. The TA will support the 
participation of leaders from over 40  DMCs at the first APWS.13 Leaders will be encouraged to 
showcase  tangible  results,  reflected  in  greater  water  investments,  the  adoption  and

progress toward the MDGs.   
 
15.  The first APWS will focus on the priority themes of the APWF: water financing, water-
related disaster management, and water for development and ecosystems. Under the activities 
supported by the CFWS, ADB will also produce knowledge products on issues, lessons learned, 
and a strategic approach for the way forward that will help to prepare recommendations on 
water financing. It will aim to rally political support and institutional frameworks to finance water-
related infrastructure and capacity development.  
 
16.  As with other lead institutions, ADB will make in-kind contributions to the APWF through 
complementary activities funded by the CFWS.14 With support from CFWS, ADB will prepare 
success stories for the media on how water infrastructure investments in the region, including 
ADB-supported projects, have resulted in poverty reduction and economic growth, which in turn 
has translated into a better lifestyle and opportunities for the people. These stories will be 
presented to attract the attention of leaders and policy makers, as well as the media.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan.15  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. ADB’s Energy, Transport, and Water 
Division of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) will implement the 
TA, in cooperation with ADB’s operations departments; the Department of External Relations; 
the Water Committee; JWF; and lead institutions of the APWF.  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 24 months, starting in April 2007 and 
ending in March 2009. The services of a media coordinator (international consultant, 2 person-
months will be required to support the preparation and implementation of a strategy to promote 
the first APWS. The services of a water sector expert (national consultant, 8 person-months) will 
be needed in ADB headquarters for day-to-day coordination of TA activities. The TA will also 
support the APWF Governing Council and the Steering Committee for the first APWS. 
 
20.  AWDO will be prepared by a dedicated team of international and national consultants, 
led  by  an  international  water  sector  expert,  working  in  close  coordination  with  a  panel  of 
resource persons. All consultants and resource persons will be engaged as individuals by ADB 
in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2006, as amended from time to 
time).  Procurement  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2006,  as 
amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consulting services are in

BACKGROUND INFORMATION ON THE ASIA-PACIFIC WATER FORUM  
AND ASIA-PACIFIC WATER SUMMIT1
 
1.  Goal and Objectives of the APWF. The Asia-Pacific Water Forum (APWF) aims to 
contribute  to  sustainable  water  management  and  the  achievement  of  the  Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) in Asia. Its objectives are: (i) to provide countries and organizations 
in the region with a common platform for articulating strategies and promoting achievements in 
solving water problems, including meeting the necessary investment requirements; and (ii) to 
showcase leadership in decision-making, excellence in practice and innovation, and results that 
have had a substantial impact at the grassroots level. 
  
2.  Priority Themes and Key Result Areas of APWF.  In order to meet its objectives, the 
APWF  will  have  three  priority  themes:  (i)  water  financing,  (ii)  disaster  management,  and 
(iii) water for development and ecosystems.  Progress on each priority theme will be presented 
at the Asia-Pacific water summits.  APWF will work on five key result areas (KRAs), each of 
which will encompass a specific set of related activities. The KRAs are essentially the means 
through which the APWF will achieve progress toward meeting the targets in each of the three 
priority themes. The three priority themes, five KRAs, and the lead organizations are presented 
in Tables A2.1 and A2.2.

3.  Water Financing. The Asia and Pacific region is expected to experience unprecedented 
economic development over the coming decades.  This, combined with population growth, is 
likely to increase pressure on already stressed water resources.  However, if supported by 
political will and institutional frameworks, this anticipated growth can provide opportunities for 
financing water-related infrastructure and human capacity development.   
 
4.  In less developed countries where the need for new infrastructure is greatest, additional 
investments  will  be  required  for  education  to  improve  operation  and  maintenance  and  to 
enhance existing infrastructure. Investments in new infrastructure need to be combined with 
increased investments in education so the value of the new infrastructure is maximized. 
 
5.  Greater efforts will need to be made to attract new funding sources and to develop 
innovative financial mechanisms.  Priority should be given to programs that invest in capacity 
development for people and institutions and build self-reliance.   
 
6.   Disaster Management. Between 2001 and 2005, an average of over 62,000 people 
were killed every year by water-related disasters in the Asia and Pacific region. Vulnerability to 
water-related disasters remains high across the region, from flash floods and landslides in 
mountainous areas to monsoon-related flooding in deltas. The plea from the Hyogo Framework 
for Action 2005–2015,2 to halve the number of deaths caused by water-related disasters, may 
be used as a target for the region.  
 
7.  Enhancing preparedness through better early warning systems, stronger regional co-
operation, and more awareness and community involvement are central to addressing this 
priority theme.  The increasing risks that climate change poses, especially in coastal urban 
areas, make the need for action all the more urgent.  Small island states, especially in the 
Pacific, are highly vulnerable to climate extremes and variability. Pre-emptive efforts are needed 
to build resilience within communities and to protect the livelihoods of the most vulnerable, 
especially women and children. 
 
8.  APWF will look beyond coping with hazards and will also pay attention to reducing 
vulnerability.  The key to reducing vulnerability lies in increasing preparedness through pre-
emptive activities, such as early warning systems, raising awareness and evacuation planning.

9.  Water  for  Development  and  Ecosystems.  Healthy  aquatic  ecosystems  provide 
tangible economic and social benefits.  Protecting zones at the land–water interface such as 
mangroves, paddy fields, wetlands, and forests not only increases ecosystem health, but may 
provide extra protection against disasters and saline intrusion, help groundwater recharging, 
and improve the overall quality of life. 
 
10.  In  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region,  the  importance  of  “natural  water”  as  part  of  the 
environment has been embraced by many cultures.  Unfortunately, modernization has resulted 
in far too many water courses being dramatically “denaturalized”.  Surface water restoration is 
not only good for the environment and the integrity of the water resources, it can have tangible 
social benefits as well, including reducing flood vulnerability and increasing the overall quality of 
life by providing people who live in or frequent the area with new areas of natural beauty for 
recreation and relaxation. 
 
11.  Governance Structure of APWF. The proposed governance structure for the APWF 
consists of: (i) president and advisers; (ii) governing council consisting of a chair and two vice-
chairs;  (iii)  subregional  coordinators;  (iv)  lead  organizations  for  priority  themes  and  KRAs; 
(v) member organizations; and (vi) a secretariat.  The intent is to have a light managerial and 
administrative set-up responsible for coordinating APWF activities, including the organization of 
the Asia-Pacific Water Summits.     
 
12.  The  subregional  coordinators  are  the  organizations  in  the  five  subregions 3   that 
represented Asia and the Pacific during the preparatory process leading up to the fourth WWF 
and prepared the regional document that led to the ministerial declaration and, ultimately, to the 
creation of the APWF. Like the subregional coordinators, the lead organizations have agreed to 
operate on a voluntary basis and have expressed their willingness to commit the resources 
necessary to cover their active participation.  They are also part of a wide network of local 
practitioners, with access to decision-makers, and are thus able to build links between the 
grassroots and governmental levels. 
 
13.  Asia-Pacific Water Summits.  At the fourth WWF the ministerial meeting also called on 
the APWF to organize Asia-Pacific water summits once every 2 or 3 years.  It was agreed that 
first summit would be held in Japan in 2007.  Succeeding summits will be organized in countries 
of Asia and the Pacific region, depending upon proposals received.   
 
14.  The first summit in Japan will be held in Beppu City, Oita Prefecture on 3–4 December 
2007. The Government of Japan will support the summit. The organizers are the Asia-Pacific 
Water Forum and the steering committee of the first Asia-Pacific Water Summit, consisting of 
eminent persons from Japan and other countries in the region.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Asian Water Development Outlook 
1.  The Asian Water Development Outlook (AWDO) will serve as a decision-making guide on 
the water sector for leaders and policy makers in the region. It will comprise an overview chapter of 
the region; several background analytical papers on issues affecting the water sector; and country 
chapters. The accompanying CD will include an interactive tool for querying and analyzing country 
data on key water development indicators. 
 
2.  A team of international (total 8 person-months) and national consultants (total 8 person-
months) and resource persons will be hired as individuals to prepare the AWDO. Under the direct 
supervision of ADB’s Principal Water Supply and Sanitation Specialist in RSDD, the consultants 
and resource persons will work with the ADB’s Water committee, APWF governing council, and 
lead institutions of APWF to develop the outline and the table of contents for the first AWDO.  
 
3.  An international water sector expert will be engaged for 3 person-months, to lead the team. 
The team leader will be responsible for the overall content and quality of the AWDO. The resource 
persons will provide inputs and background papers on issues in the sector, and contribute to the 
overview chapter of the water sector in Asia, and recommendations for leaders of governments to 
commit to at the first Asia-Pacific Water Summit (APWS).  
 
4.  The  international  and  national  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  the  issues  chapter, 
country  chapters,  including  data  gathering,  analysis,  and  undertaking  research  and  other 
assignments  as  required.  The  team  will  also  be  responsible  for  report  finalization,  including 
typesetting, proofreading, copyediting, and desktop publishing, working closely with the respective 
editors; the staff in ADB’s regional departments; the Water Committee, Energy, Transport, and 
Water  Division  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  (RSDD);  and  the 
Department  of  External  Relations.  The  international  consultants  should  have  extensive  water 
sector experience and a good knowledge of developing member countries.  
 
5.  The resource persons should have extensive working experience in Asia and Pacific water 
sector issues. Working closely with the team, they will (i) provide inputs and materials for the 
thematic chapter and country chapters of AWDO; (ii) participate in expert workshops for designing 
the table of contents of AWDO, and reviewing the draft AWDO; and (iii) review and comment on 
input data and analysis on water sector indicators in AWDO. 
 
6.  Technical Content Editor. Under the supervision of ADB’s principal water supply and 
sanitation specialist in RSDD, the technical content editor will be engaged for 2 person-months, to 
edit the manuscripts for consistency and economic content. The editor will assist in preparing the 
highlights of the publication and will ensure that all data are based on the most recent and relevant 
information available. The editor will: 
 
(i)  edit AWDO to ensure consistency between data and policy, 
(ii)  edit AWDO to ensure internal consistency, 
(iii)  edit AWDO to ensure balanced coverage and degree of detail and precision, 
(iv)  check the report for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to 
requirements, 
(v)  review the accuracy and validity of information, tables and charts included, 
(vi)  assist in preparing publication highlights, and 
(vii)  help prepare key messages and review press release drafts.

Appendix 4  13 
C.  TA Coordinator  
9.  A national consultant (8 person-months) familiar with ADB operations in the water sector 
will coordinate the TA implementation, particularly the activities related to the production of the 
AWDO, and the preparation and conduct of the first APWS.  Specifically, the TA coordinator will 
carry out the following tasks. 
1.  Preparations for and Conduct of the Asia-Pacific Water Summit 
 
(i)  Coordinate with JWF in preparing the summit program and design, and provide 
inputs as necessary (e.g., on structure, speakers, and topics); 
(ii)  work closely with JWF in identifying participants, particularly those from developing 
member countries; 
(iii)  liaise closely with JWF on all administrative and logistical arrangements (e.g., travel 
costs of participants, hotels and other accommodation); 
(iv)  coordinate  with  the  media  coordinator  to  draw  up  a  communication  plan  (both 
internal and external) to make sure that information about the summit is adequately 
communicated on time, i.e., in ADB Today, on the ADB website, and in press 
releases; and  
(v)  prepare periodic progress reports to keep management updated on the status of 
preparations, including information about issues encountered and actions required 
from ADB. 
 
2.  Preparation of Asian Water Development Outlook 
 
(i)  Participate in discussions on the ADO outline and scope and contribute technical 
inputs; 
(ii)  help facilitate contractual arrangements for the engagement of the panel members; 
(iii)  coordinate in the review of drafts to be submitted periodically to ADB for review; 
(iv)  coordinate  printing,  reproduction  and  dissemination  of  finished  products,  either 
directly or through contracted parties; and 
(v)  coordinate communication plan to disseminate information about ADO. 
 
3.  Administration of the Regional Technical Assistance 
 
(i)  Prepare periodic reports, e.g., financial  and accomplishment reports; 
(ii)  review liquidation reports before endorsing for payment; 
(iii)  coordinate with JWF all financial reports required to facilitate transfer of funds and/or 
payment of expenses; and  
(iv)  prepare final report and TA completion report.
